official-title.#text:
To make certain luggage and travel articles eligible for
		  duty-free treatment under the Generalized System of Preferences, and for other
		  purposes.

cosponsor.#tail:
)
			 introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
GSP Update for Production
			 Diversification and Trade Enhancement Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

The Generalized
			 System of Preferences under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
was enacted to promote economic development in developing and
			 least-developed countries.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: title V of the Trade Act of 1974

text.#text:
Many articles
			 referred to as luggage or travel articles and classified under chapter 42 of
			 the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States may not be designated as
			 eligible articles for purposes of the Generalized System of Preferences.

Global trade and
			 manufacturing dynamics have changed since the enactment of the Generalized
			 System of Preferences in 1974, and many luggage and travel articles may no
			 longer be import-sensitive to industries in the United States.

By removing
			 certain luggage and travel articles from the list of articles excluded from
			 eligibility under the Generalized System of Preferences, Congress is not
			 changing rates in the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States, but
			 instead is allowing those articles access to the annual review process under
			 the Generalized System of Preferences, which relies on investigations and
			 recommendations from the independent United States International Trade
			 Commission, among other agencies of the United States Government.

As of February
			 2012, 73 of the 132 countries designated as beneficiary developing countries
			 under the Generalized System of Preferences export articles classified under
			 heading 4202 of the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States to the
			 United States. Twenty of those countries have been designated as
			 least-developed beneficiary developing countries for purposes of the
			 Generalized System of Preferences.

As of February
			 2012, the People's Republic of China has a nearly 80 percent share of the
			 market for certain luggage and travel articles being imported into the United
			 States. This dominance leaves little room for competition from smaller
			 developing countries. For example, countries designated as beneficiary
			 developing countries under the Generalized System of Preferences account for
			 only 5 percent of imports of those articles into the United States.

The provision of
			 duty-free treatment under the Generalized System of Preferences for certain
			 luggage and travel articles imported into the United States may result in a
			 shift in the production of those articles from China to countries designated as
			 beneficiary developing countries or least-developed beneficiary developing
			 countries under the Generalized System of Preferences.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 503(b)(1) of the Trade Act of 1974
